name: Hit-Bit F9
keyboard: Full-stroke 92 key with arrow and numeric keypads
rom: 96 KB (48 KB BASIC, 48 KB built-in software)
graphics: 9 graphic modes, the most used is 256 x 212 with 256 colors
ports: RF TV connector, RGB video output, audio/video output (composite), Tape connector, Parallel/printer connector,  2 cartridge slots,  2 controller ports
description:
The Sony HIT BIT F9P was a MSX 2 standard machine with no built-in floppy drive.

Along with MSX BASIC, several software were provided in ROM:
- Personal data and notes
- Calendar and alarm
- System Setup interface.

Foreign models where named HB-F9S for Spain, HB-F9F for France, HB-F9D for Germany or HB-F9P for PAL systems...

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> HB-F9S CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>Close-up of the spanish version. Notice the "tilde" key (next to the "L")</blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice advert, although a little excessive.<p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #6</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, July 1982 issue.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The sound, the color, the intelligence''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 6000 MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> WE HAVE A NEW APPROACH TO DISTRIBUTED PROCESSING THAT WORKS <br><br> Already implemented are electronic mail, word processing, complete cost accounting with inventory control and more. The secret is a new technology called Functionally Structured Distribution (FSD). At last, a system to organize and manage distributed processing applications that is really up and running. FSD technology is especially applicable to installa­tions that require:<br> • Unlimited expandability supporting extremely large data bases and terminals in many cities.<br> • User-friendly software easily programmed in high level languages (COBOL, FORTRAN, and BASIC)<br> • System reliability (due to distributed hardware) while maintaining multiple levels of data security.<br> • Compatibility with existing mainframes and networks (including the Bell System). <br><br> We are presently installing Billings 6000 Computer Systems which take full advantage of distributed processing utilizing FSD technology. The 6000 Computer supports multiple hard disk drives with capacities of up to 64 Mbytes (formatted), streaming tapes for backup, auto-dial modems (2400 baud synchronous) for communications, and flexible disk drives for smaller installations.</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">No one knows better than Microsoft how to increase your TRS-80 BASIC's power. Microsoft created the TRS-80 Level ll and Disk BASIC plus the industry standard Microsoft BASIC...<br><br> ...Microsoft Level lll BASIC is an enhancement to the Level ll. It contains all Disk BASIC features not already in Level ll and it adds six new Level lll exclusives...<br> ...Advanced graphics is Level lll's most exciting addition to the TRS-80 - and it's exclusive. Draw a line, outline or solid box by specifying just two points, then save it and put it back with BASIC statement. You'll find yourself writing more programs with charts, graphs and even animation...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1ST. U.S. ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Each picture represents a customers target. Three of them are well known: Home/entertainement,  office and educational uses. A fourth one is added for the first time, the senior citizens. Epson thought the QX-10 was user-friendly enough to be used by retired people.   </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOFTCARD COPY</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert for one of the numerous copies of the Microsoft SotfCard. Initially, they were manufactured in the United States then in Asia.   </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> CORTEX has been designed not to dominate your desk, to leave room for your calendar, your telephone, your in-tray and the rest. If you want it inconspicuous, buy iy in conventional cream. But for extroverts, and the fashion conscious, CORTEX comes in bright, bright colours - warm red, C/WP green, sunshine yellow, ice white and all black...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"You hesitate between two standards."<br> "Rank Xerox doesn't."</blockquote>

emulator.name: fMSX32
emulator.description: The excellent fMSX, but ported onto the GamePark GP32 handheld console.

emulator.name: openMSX - The MSX emulator that aims for perfection.
emulator.description: This new MSX emulator can reproduce, among many other MSX, MSX2and  MSX2+ machines, both Panasonic Turbo-R models. Be sure to get the catapult frontend and the system roms from FUNET.
